5. As quoted in Clive Cookson (1995). Cookson reports that [t]oday, genetic engineering is used daily as a laboratory tool by every research-based pharmaceutical and biotech company.
17. Zucker, Darby, and Armstrong (1998) present some evidence that entrants may be more successful in biotech research than incumbents.

20. Zucker, Darby, and Brewer (1998) report that both stars and collaborators have positive effects in the corresponding model for the U.S. Differences between the U.S. and Japan will be explored in Section VI below. Note, however, that in long-run poisson regressions (not feasible here because of the smaller number of prefectures than U.S. BEAs) Zucker, Darby, and Brewer (1998) do find some evidence of negative effects of the number of active collaborators.

21. The two broader definitions (b) and (c) were based on Dodwell Marketing Consultants Industrial Groupings in Japan. The narrower definitions (a) and (d) were based on Keizai Chosa Kyokais Keiretsu no Kenkyu (KNK). (Weinstein and Yishay Yafeh 1995, p. 367.)
